imo it isnt a plot hole. shanks was just way too preoccupied with keeping luffy safe and he really didnt give a shit about himself at this point. 

he isnt even upset at losing his arm, he even told whitebeard i think or mihawk, when asked "what happened to ur arm", "i made a bet on the future". 

obviously he didnt do this to lose his arm, but his arm being lost is a sign that he supports luffy in his KOTP dream.

of course there's also the effect that he wants to teach luffy a lesson about picking a fight, which was very very successful

it is its own letter, so its not interchangeable. some words like daß or schluß were recently spelled like dass or schluss, but its not common. 

words like weiß or stoß for example, cannot be spelt like weiss or stoss (unless you are swiss, then they have their own thing going on)

it felt a lot more shonen than OPM for sure. comedy anime always poke fun at tropes made by shonen anime, like when i think of comedy anime i think of OPM, saiki k, gintama. 

mob psycho IS just shonen. it may be funny, but its just shonen - about a young boy grasping his powers, thats typical shonen. as i said - calling mob psycho comedy is like calling jjk comedy. its funny, but its not comedy anime. 

see that by itself is just fine. but my problem is that it got advertised as a comedy anime, then when i went into it expecting comedy anime, and got a shonen, Mob Psycho fans try to gaslight me into thinking that it was never advertised as a comedy.

One piece filler is actually not bad. Some episodes when I realised that they were filler, i was quite schocked. 

there was one episode about Sanji teaching a marine boy how to cook. i really liked it, it was filler. There was an arc about the Straw Hats losing their flag and having to get it back without Luffy knowing. It was obviously filler, but i still liked it. post enies lobby was like i think the 3rd or 4th time Sanji ever mentioned the All Blue (he hardly mentions it after Baratie), but the anime makes sure to mention it again. The Kungfu Dugongs I was really surprised that they were filler (and really sad). 

On the other hand, I was surprised that the Foxy Pirates Arc was a lot shorter in the manga. I enjoyed the arc but it did feel long (but Afro Luffy was worth it) 

Of course also, Condo D. Oriano and the G8 arc is goated

Naruto. 

My anime friends kept saying "watch naruto! watch naruto!" Especially because Ihad watched OP and bleach already, but I've never finished naruto. I've tried, first time I got to just before the Chunin Exam, second time i got to during the Chunin exam, third time i actually got to the introduction of pain. then the fourth time i managed to finish it.

I think it's because i prefer watching comedy animes and I was also watching OP while watching naruto, so subconsciousl i kept thinking "damn naruto makes me feel so depressed, i should watch some OP to balance it out". But then the plot of naruto just genuinely became bad somewhere near the end and I remember that at some point towards the end i was just like "man this sucks" and then it turns out that actually the black and white man had been controlling everyone this whole time? and i just felt like it had been a huge waste of time for me. 

i do admit that OP just being a more light hearted anime had something to do with it, but i genuinely think towards the end of naruto, i just had this feeling that i had wasted all this time. :/

i editted my response a few times because i had to search up how to use 了 . hope you saw the new updates!

sflr i didn't receive notifications for some reason. 

??? im confused about the 4 examples you gave lol. 

yes I'm a native speaker. 了 is nornally used like

“吃饱了吗？” (are you already full?)

 “吃饱了” (im already full)

“功课你做完了吗？” (have you finished your homework already)

“做完了” (finished my homework already)

but to be honest, you need the 了 if not it sounds incomplete. Like you cannot respond to 吃饱了吗 with 吃饱. 

(side note: 吃饱吗 sounds okay to me but i feel like grammatically that's wrong? idk sorry im not a chinese teacher i just go based on gut feeling)

i think i kinda understand the change in state. 

like you can say “我变成了个姑娘！” (i became a woman!)

if you remove it it sounds like in the future you will become a woman

when i search online it seems like there are 2 uses for 了

1. to mark that an action is completed (or, already done)

i.e. 吃完了 (the plate is empty now)

他走了 (he already left, probably a long time ago)

他刚走了 (he already left, a short time ago)

我学会了华语 (i've mastered the chinese language)

你已经迟到了 (you are already late)

2. to mark that something has changed into something (used with verbs that mean "change") (but actually this meaning is like the one above, because it means that the transformation is complete)

i.e. 这碗汤冻成冰了 (this soup froze already/became ice)

你成为了一个优秀的学成 (you became into a great student)

这张纸变成了一个飞机 (this paper became an airplane)

people do wear something like kebayas in real life. it's definitely a fashion thing. I know my peranakan grandmother would wear something like a kebaya but little more casual (i.e. pants instead of skirt), and i've seen people wear the kebaya skirt with just a tank top. There are looser, casual versions of the kebaya that people do wear in everyday lives. some malay muslim people when they go to the mosque will wear batik prints (which is the print that kinda looks like the prints on kebayas). 

dont get me wrong, the absolute average singaporean would just wear something from uniqlo, shorts and slippers, but you do have the occasional fashionista wearing more traditional clothing. (kebaya/batik and sarong and sari are more common to see casually than cheong sam but yeah)

disclaimer: im not a fashion historian or what, i just am an average sgean speaking from personal experience.


edit: if you are visiting singapore and want to get your mum something like that, visit arab street, they have lots of shops doing kebaya/nonya kebaya. i mean you could also probably go to malaysia or indonesia, which is probably cheaper
